review: This book is a heartfelt romance that skillfully weaves together heavier themes such as grief, divorce, motherhood, and self-discovery with lighthearted, heartwarming moments. It transcends typical light and sexy romances, offering depth and relatability that sets it apart in the contemporary romance genre.

The main characters, Ali and Ethan, are relatable, flawed, and beautifully developed. Their electric chemistry and charming flirty banter make their love story feel gentle, kind, and authentic. Their personal growth unfolds naturally and convincingly. The romance is a slow burn, adopting a closed-door/fade-to-black approach, yet the depth of their relationship is compelling enough to shine without explicit scenes. With plenty of sexually charged moments and PG-13 action, the anticipation and emotional connection only deepen.

The author's writing is charming and emotionally engaging, making the story both accessible and hard to put down. Its skillful blend of humor, depth, and sweetness captivates the reader from start to finish.

Despite differing life experiences, such as loss, divorce, or motherhood, the reader quickly forms a deep connection to the characters and their journeys. The story's universal themes and well-developed characters create a lasting emotional impact.
conclusion: *Summer Romance* is a delightful, heartfelt novel that masterfully blends heavier themes with lighthearted moments. With its relatable characters, charming romance, and engaging writing, it‚Äôs a standout in the contemporary romance genre. Despite its closed-door approach, the story‚Äôs emotional depth and chemistry make it a compelling read.

Ali Morris is a quirky and relatable character who has faced significant hardships, including being left by her husband on the second anniversary of her mother‚Äôs death, raising three kids, and finding solace in reorganizing her closet as a form of meditation. review: SUMMER ROMANCE follows Ali Morris, a professional organizer who struggles with chaos in her own life. As she deals with her divorce and the grief from her mother's passing, Ali embarks on a journey of self-discovery. She learns to value her own voice, eliminate clutter and toxic influences, and ultimately open her heart to love again. The story explores themes of navigating divorce, single parenthood, moving on from unhealthy relationships, and honoring those we've lost.

This story is both genuine and tender, filled with moments that brought me to tears. As someone facing a similar personal challenge, I found Ali's journey incredibly relatable, leaving me with a sense of understanding and hope. The book captures everyday experiences perfectly‚Äîmessy pantries, navigating dog park culture, and the quirks of dogs with human names. It explores themes like eggs as a love language, the humor of Costco underwear, and recognizing personal strengths, ultimately inspiring readers to embrace their best selves.

This might be my favorite book by this author yet! I stayed up until 3 a.m. to finish it in just two sittings‚Äîit‚Äôs that captivating. From the very first page, I felt genuine butterflies, something I haven‚Äôt experienced in a long time. The romance had me kicking my feet and giggling, and I cherished every moment. I truly didn‚Äôt want this book to end! It was filled with humor, heart, and major swoon-worthy moments, complete with charm bracelets and mildly aggressive texts about limes and showering with glasses on. Such a fun read!

A captivating tale of transformation and romance! It follows a rebellious boy as he evolves into a mature man, falling head over heels first. The pantry kisses and the effervescent thrill of love beautifully capture the essence of this enchanting story.
conclusion: SUMMER ROMANCE by the author is an absolute gem of a book, blending humor, heart, and swoon-worthy romance with deeply relatable themes of grief, divorce, and self-discovery. Ali Morris's journey is tender, genuine, and emotionally resonant, leaving readers feeling seen and hopeful. The book is captivating from the first page, with moments that evoke laughter, tears, and butterflies. It‚Äôs a story that stays with you long after the last page, and I‚Äôm so grateful to the author for sharing it.

review: The plot centers on the characters' emotional journeys rather than traditional action, which might not appeal to every reader. However, I found the emotional depth and character development compelling enough to sustain the story.

The characters are the highlight of this novel. Each one, from Ali and her children to Ethan and his family, feels authentic and fully developed. Their vulnerabilities render them both lovable and relatable, with the exception of Pete, who comes off as unlikable. The depth of their personalities makes the story emotionally engaging, though at times it was so intense that I needed to pause for a breather.

The emotional journey of Ethan and Ali was profoundly moving. Their thrilling love story, marked by struggles to communicate and confront their fears, resonated deeply with me. The relatability of their experiences created an immersive narrative, though it occasionally felt overwhelming.

This love story was beautifully romantic and kept me fully engaged throughout. Although I would have preferred more explicit scenes, the emotional connection between the characters was so captivating that I never felt bored.
conclusion: This novel is a deeply emotional and character-driven love story that excels in creating relatable, fully formed characters. While the lack of a traditional plot might not appeal to everyone, the romantic and emotional journey of Ethan and Ali kept me thoroughly engaged. I would happily read more books set in this world.

review: This novel is a delightful second-chance romance that delves into themes of change, new beginnings, and enduring love. It follows Ali Morris, a professional organizer whose life is tumultuous after years in an unhappy marriage and raising three demanding children. As Ali navigates her grief over her mother's passing, an impending divorce, and the prospect of new love, the story beautifully captures her transformative journey.

Ali emerges as a relatable and resilient protagonist, poised to embrace a new chapter in her life. Her charming connection with Ethan begins at a dog park through an endearing "meet cute," facilitated by her dog, Ferris. Ethan injects a sense of youthfulness and adoration into Ali's life, making their bond feel both genuine and heartwarming. However, their blossoming romance is complicated by Ethan's true identity, which initially places him out of reach. Despite the challenges they face, the story beautifully illustrates that love can endure and flourish even in messy circumstances.

Monaghan crafts a delightful summer read with a light, engaging tone that balances humor and emotional depth. The narrative features charming moments, like the dog park scene, beautifully capturing the essence of summer romance.
conclusion: *SUMMER ROMANCE* is a heartwarming and engaging story of second chances, personal growth, and the enduring power of love. Ali‚Äôs journey is relatable and inspiring, and her connection with Ethan adds a delightful layer of romance and hope. The author has crafted another summer gem that is both emotionally resonant and uplifting.

review: The protagonist, Ali, is a relatable and multifaceted character grappling with a pending divorce, the loss of her mother, and low self-confidence, which makes her journey of self-discovery compelling. The supporting cast, including Ali's children, friends, and the vibrant beach community, enriches the narrative, with each character playing a meaningful role in Ali's and Ethan's relationship. The novel effectively delves into themes of self-worth, personal growth, and reclaiming dignity, which are central to Ali's journey. Its emotional depth is heightened by a realistic depiction of grief, divorce, and the challenges of starting anew.
conclusion: This novel is a heartfelt and well-crafted story about love, self-discovery, and second chances. review: Ethan and Ali's relationship is an exemplary portrayal of mature, balanced love. Their connection, free from drama, beautifully captures the complexity of a true partnership through understanding and forgiveness. The romance thrives on the profound simplicity of allowing oneself to be fully known and loved. Ali grapples with reclaiming her identity lost in marriage, while Ethan strives to shed the image of the lost boy he once was. Both characters resonate deeply, prompting readers to reflect on their own journeys. The book's true magic lies in its ability to unmoor readers, making them feel seen and understood through the characters‚Äô experiences.

The author‚Äôs writing is both simple and powerful, uplifting readers and instilling a sense of hope. The romance is quiet and understated, highlighting small actions, comfortable silences, and the profound beauty of being fully understood. Rather than grand gestures, the prose celebrates the elegance of everyday moments in love.

This book reads like a heartfelt love letter to one's past self, filled with reassurance that everything will eventually be alright. It delves into various facets of grief‚Äîover a failed marriage, the loss of a mother, and the loss of a former self. The narrative intricately weaves these themes, highlighting how Ali‚Äôs marriage diminished her sense of self, fueled by her mother's aspiration for her to lead a perfect life. In contrast, Ethan's grief stems from mourning the person others still expect him to be, revealing his frustrations with their unexpected reactions to his growth.

This book offered a profound healing experience, prompting me to reevaluate my previous rejection of dating and marriage. It encouraged introspection on themes of vulnerability, love, and the unpredictability of relationships. Ultimately, the story opened my heart to the possibility of discovering a connection like that of Ethan and Ali.
conclusion: *Summer Romance* is a deeply moving and relatable novel that explores grief, self-discovery, and the quiet beauty of love. Through its mature and balanced portrayal of relationships, it challenges readers to reflect on their own lives and beliefs about love. The author‚Äôs writing is both simple and powerful, making this book a standout in the romance genre. It‚Äôs a story that feels like a personal sign, offering healing and hope, and is undoubtedly one of the best romance books I have ever encountered.

review: This novel is a heartwarming summer romance that centers on a single mom, a reverse age gap, and the best friend's little brother trope. The story follows Ali as she navigates the grief of losing her mother and the aftermath of an unhappy marriage. Her journey takes a turn when she reconnects with Ethan, her best friend's younger brother, who has long harbored a crush on her.

Ali is a relatable protagonist whose significant personal growth makes her journey compelling and emotionally resonant. Ethan, affectionately nicknamed 'Scooter,' is swoon-worthy and sweet, providing a no-strings-attached summer romance while assisting Ali with her divorce in exchange for her organizational skills.
This book is both swoon-worthy and heartfelt, addressing complex subjects with sensitivity and depth. The author's engaging storytelling ensures a quick and enjoyable read.

This story delves into themes of self-discovery, single parenthood, divorce, grief, new love, loss, and the intricacies of interpersonal relationships, including romantic connections, friendships, and co-parenting dynamics.
This novel masterfully evokes a spectrum of emotions, from joy to heartache. I felt a strong connection to Ali‚Äôs journey and raced through the pages, finding the story both relatable and moving.

This book is a must-read for summer and is highly recommended, particularly for fans of authors like Ali Brady and Sarah Morgan. I intend to buy a copy upon its release and will definitely recommend it to friends.
conclusion: This novel is a heartfelt and emotionally rich summer romance that skillfully balances swoony moments with deeper explorations of grief, self-discovery, and love. With relatable characters and a compelling narrative, it‚Äôs a must-read for fans of contemporary romance.

review: The story opens with Ali feeling stuck in a rut, dressed in sweatpants and spending time with her elderly neighbor. Her life takes a turn when she meets Ethan at the dog park, and romantic tension quickly develops as Ali grapples with her feelings for him‚Äîespecially upon discovering he is Scooter, her friend‚Äôs younger brother. The pacing effectively maintains my interest, leaving me eager to see if their romance will endure beyond the summer.

Ali Morris is a deeply relatable protagonist who navigates grief following her mother's death, the challenges of raising three children, and a divorce from her self-absorbed husband, Pete. Ethan (Scooter), initially an annoying high school peer, evolves into a mature, determined man with a long-standing crush on Ali, adding depth to the narrative. The characters are well-developed and engaging, making Ali and Ethan especially easy to root for. Supporting characters, including Ali's children and her elderly neighbor, bring additional charm and richness to the story.
The author's engaging and light writing style makes *Summer Romance* an ideal beach read. Its warm, humorous tone effectively balances deeper themes with moments of levity.

The novel poignantly delves into themes of grief, self-discovery, and second chances, rendering it emotionally resonant and relatable. Ali's journey to rediscover her former self and find love once more is both heartwarming and inspiring.
conclusion: *Summer Romance* by the author is a delightful and relatable beach read that combines humor, heart, and emotional depth. The story of Ali and Ethan's evolving relationship is both heartwarming and engaging, with well-crafted characters and a plot that keeps you hooked. It‚Äôs a perfect blend of romance and self-discovery, making it a standout summer novel.

review:
Ali Morris' life has unraveled since her mother's death two years ago, compounded by her ex-husband's request for a divorce on the one-year anniversary of her loss. Consumed by grief, she struggles to maintain her role as a mother while grappling with her own self-worth. At the start of the book, Ali is clearly depressed, going through the motions to keep her life and children intact. 

As a protagonist, Ali is strong, relatable, and complex‚Äîqualities I appreciated, especially as a mother navigating life post-divorce. It's refreshing to see a character like her as the female lead in a romance, as stories often overlook such perspectives. Ali is caring and headstrong but deeply vulnerable, wrestling with her emotions while fearing loss if she opens her heart again. 

Her chance encounter with Ethan at a dog park ignites an unexpected spark. However, Ali is unsure how to start dating again after her failed marriage. I adored Ethan for his gentle, supportive nature as he helps coax Ali out of her shell. His commitment to her children and his transition from a high-profile law firm to public interest work only add to his charm. Despite the focus on Ali‚Äôs journey, the book also thoughtfully explores the toxic pressures Ethan faces in his own life, adding depth to both characters.

In a romance novel, I look for strong characters, palpable tension and chemistry, humor, and engaging banter, but above all, depth and emotion. This book delivered on all fronts! I particularly appreciated its themes of grief and loss. It was evident that the author drew from personal experiences to portray these emotions poignantly, enhancing the authenticity of the story and its characters. I especially loved how Ali's conversations with her mother throughout the narrative helped her gradually heal from the profound ache of loss.

This was the perfect summer romance for me! *Summer Romance* gave me all the best Emily Henry vibes. It‚Äôs an ideal read for the beach, offering a fun escape filled with warmth and sunshine. Not only is it captivating, but it also explores a variety of themes that keep you engaged. I couldn‚Äôt put it down and finished it in a day, highlighting numerous lines along the way. I can‚Äôt wait to revisit this delightful book!
conclusion: This book is a perfect blend of a fun summer romance and a deeply emotional exploration of grief, loss, and self-discovery. With strong character development, heartfelt chemistry, and poignant themes, it‚Äôs a captivating read that I couldn‚Äôt put down and can‚Äôt wait to revisit.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Overall Appeal and Genre Fit:**  
   - This was the PERFECT summer romance for me.  
   - Summer Romance gave me Emily Henry vibes in the best way.  
   - If you want a fun summer romance perfect for the beach and for the warm weather and sunshine, while also looking for a romance that will keep you captivated and explore so many different themes, this book is for you!  

- **Character Development (Ali Morris):**  
   - Ali Morris' life has fallen apart since she lost her mother two years ago...and her ex-husband asked her for a divorce on the one-year anniversary of losing her mother.  
   - Ali has lost herself in her grief, the regular motions of being a mother, and failing to see her self-worth.  
   - Ali starts the book deep in a funk, clearly depressed and going through the motions to try and keep her life together and her kids moving.  
   - Ali was such a strong and fun female main character.  
   - I loved how this book followed a female main character coming out of a divorce, especially because having a mom as the female love interest isn't in many of the romance books I read.  
   - Ali is so caring, headstrong, yet vulnerable and has learned to shove her emotions in a ball.  
   - She is overcome by her grief and her fear over losing the people she loves if she lets people get to her heart.  

- **Romantic Chemistry and Dynamics (Ali and Ethan):**  
   - She meets Ethan in the dog park one day, and sparks instantly fly for Ali, who has no idea how to go about dating someone new after her failed marriage.  
   - I LOVED the way Ethan showed up for Ali and slowly coaxed her out of her shell.  
   - Showing up for Ali's kids, being a good human being, and him being a lawyer who gave up his big law firm job to do public interest work?? Yeah, that is my type of guy.  
   - Ethan was so sweet, and I loved how as much as this book focused on Ali and her issues, it also explored the toxic pressure and tension Ethan experienced in his own life.  

- **Themes and Emotional Depth:**  
   - What I look for in a romance book is a strong main character, the typical tension and chemistry between the leads, humor and banter, but most importantly, I want depth and emotion. Annabel delivered all of that in this book!  
   - I also loved the overarching themes of grief and loss throughout this book.  
   - I could tell that Annabel herself had experienced the loss of a close loved one by the way that she managed to capture the feelings of death and grief so poignantly.  
   - I think it made this book and these characters seem so much more real.  
   - I especially loved how Ali had conversations with her mom throughout the story and slowly healed from the wound of missing someone so much.  

- **Writing Style and Engagement:**  
   - I binged this book in a day, I highlighted so many lines, and I already am so excited to come back to this book and reread!!  

- **Acknowledgments:**  
   - Thank you so so much to GP Putnam and NetGalley for providing me with this advanced reader's copy in exchange for my honest review!!  

**Conclusion:**  
This book is a perfect blend of a fun summer romance and a deeply emotional exploration of grief, loss, and self-discovery. With strong character development, heartfelt chemistry, and poignant themes, it‚Äôs a captivating read that I couldn‚Äôt put down and can‚Äôt wait to revisit.

(No specific rating scores mentioned in the review.)

review: In this story, Ali, a divorced mother eager to embrace a new chapter in her life, embarks on a journey that many can relate to. The humorous circumstances surrounding her meeting with Ethan, reminiscent of a classic romantic comedy, set a lighthearted tone. Their initial chemistry and evolving connection are engaging, especially given Ethan‚Äôs ties to both Ali's past and present. The challenges they face together lend depth and authenticity to their relationship. Ethan‚Äôs dual role as both a loving partner and a steadfast support for Ali is portrayed beautifully, adding warmth to the narrative.

Annabel Monaghan has quickly become one of my favorite authors, and this book is her best yet. I appreciate her portrayal of middle-aged characters who have experienced love, as it adds depth to the story. The theme of giving love a second chance resonates with me, making this a truly enjoyable read.

While marketed as a typical summer romance, this book delves much deeper, addressing themes of grief and the challenges of single motherhood. review: The plot may not be groundbreaking, echoing themes found in *This Summer Will Be Different*, *Just For the Summer*, and *Nora Goes Off Script*, but it is executed with excellence. The true strength of the story lies in the rich character development and their journeys throughout the narrative.

In this compelling story, Ali Morris experiences profound personal growth as she moves from idolizing her mother to understanding the impact of her mother‚Äôs overprotectiveness on her own life. This realization prompts her to avoid repeating past mistakes with her children and to reclaim her independence following her marriage's end. Ethan also evolves, confronting his family about their perceptions and recognizing that he is not defined by his past. Ali‚Äôs relatability shines through her struggles with feelings of being lost, dependent, and paralyzed by the fear of loss. Her internal dilemmas, such as questioning whether decluttering the kitchen earlier could have saved her marriage, resonate deeply. The well-developed supporting characters, including the townsfolk and both Ali and Ethan‚Äôs families, enrich the narrative and add depth to the overall story.
The writing is impeccable, with no discernible issues.
conclusion: *Summer Romance* is a delightful and emotionally resonant novel, driven by its well-developed characters and vivid setting. While the plot may not be entirely unique, the execution and emotional depth make it a standout read. The audiobook narration further enhances the experience, making it a highly recommended choice for a summer read.

   - The pacing mirrors the themes of discovery and healing, creating a serene yet profound reading experience.  

- **Themes and Depth:**  
   - The story is a journey of self-discovery, both individually and through the lens of another person.  
   - It explores healing and finding strength in subtle, non-overt ways.  
   - The characters‚Äô growth feels like uncovering what‚Äôs already there, rather than building something entirely new.  

- **Use of Tropes:**  
   - While the book employs familiar romance tropes (e.g., single mom, expiration date, best friend‚Äôs brother), it transcends them, adding layers of complexity and depth.  
   - The author elevates these tropes to a level that feels fresh and masterful, making them far more than just a blip on the radar of typical romance novels.  

- **Intimacy and Sex Scenes:**  
   - The sex scenes are not explicit but are deeply meaningful, offering true insight into the intimacy and connection between the characters.  
   - These scenes serve as a device to show the growth of the relationship and the individuals involved, rather than being included for the sake of being spicy.  
   - The approach to intimacy is subtle yet effective, making it accessible to readers who may not typically enjoy explicit content.  

- **Writing Style:**  
   - The author‚Äôs writing is masterful, balancing simplicity with complexity, making the story feel both layered and effortless.  
   - The ability to take basic tropes and transform them into something extraordinary is a testament to the author‚Äôs skill.  

**Conclusion:**  
*Summer Romance* is a beautifully crafted novel that combines a serene, summery atmosphere with profound themes of self-discovery, healing, and intimacy. The author‚Äôs ability to elevate familiar tropes and create meaningful, non-explicit sex scenes makes this book stand out in the romance genre. It‚Äôs a masterful work that I highly recommend.  

**Rating Scores:**  
- Five stars. Highly, highly recommend.

review: After reconnecting with a man from high school whom she initially looked down upon, the protagonist discovers both love and her own identity. This character often embodies the "reformed bad boy" trope, where a flawed individual transforms solely through love. However, in this story, he is simply someone who, having struggled with his identity in high school and mingled with the wrong crowd, has matured over time. Despite his growth, he remains trapped in the perceptions of those from his hometown. The character development feels realistic and relatable, particularly as I appreciate authors who depict characters navigating their 30s and 40s. Ali, a soon-to-be single mother of three, grapples with her grief and the challenge of rediscovering herself after losing her identity in motherhood and an unfulfilling marriage. Her journey toward balancing authenticity, passion, and self-sacrifice is refreshing, especially in a genre where characters often swing too far in one direction while seeking identity.
The banter was genuinely witty and amusing, not only between the two love interests but also among the delightful cast of family and friends.

If you're a fan of Emily Henry and Katherine Center, you may have discovered your next favorite author. I loved *Nora Goes Off Script* two years ago, while *Same Time Next Summer* felt a bit lacking in plot. However, *Summer Romance* returns to the delightful quality of *Nora*.
conclusion: The author‚Äôs *Summer Romance* is a heartfelt and witty novel that delivers relatable characters, realistic growth, and a delightful romantic storyline. Fans of Emily Henry and Katherine Center will likely find this book to be a standout addition to their reading lists.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Author Comparison and Expectations:**  
  - If you‚Äôre a fan of Emily Henry and Katherine Center, Annabel Monaghan might be your next favorite author.  
  - I adored *Nora Goes Off Script* two years ago. *Same Time Next Summer* was fine but lacked something in the plot department. *Summer Romance* was back to the *Nora* level.  

- **Relatable Characters and Themes:**  
  - Lately, I have been very much appreciating these authors who are creating relatable characters in their 30s and 40s.  
  - Ali is a soon-to-be single, grief-stricken mother of three who has lost herself in both motherhood and a marriage where she let herself disappear.  
  - I loved seeing her learn to try to find that tricky balance between staying true to who you are, pursuing what you love, and also unselfishly sacrificing when necessary. Too often, characters searching for identity end up swinging too far to one side of that pendulum.  

- **Romantic Development and Character Growth:**  
  - After running into a man from high school (who she didn‚Äôt think too highly of at the time), she both falls in love and remembers who she is.  
  - In terms of the guy who she didn‚Äôt think too highly of in the beginning, in many books this kind of character is the ‚Äúreformed bad boy‚Äù who chooses to change just because he falls in love. That‚Äôs always a risky choice when it‚Äôs not clear if the maturity will stick. In this case, he‚Äôs just a guy who didn‚Äôt know who he was in high school, floated with the wrong crowd for a bit, and then matured; unfortunately, he ended up stuck in that place where people in your hometown or family members seem to never view you differently.  
  - The changes the characters made were realistic and relatable to me.  

- **Dialogue and Supporting Characters:**  
  - The banter was genuinely witty and funny, not just between the two love interests but also among the delightful cast of family and friend side characters.  

- **Overall Recommendation:**  
  - *Summer Romance* doesn‚Äôt come out until June, but I highly recommend adding this to your TBR now!  

**Conclusion:**  
Annabel Monaghan‚Äôs *Summer Romance* is a heartfelt and witty novel that delivers relatable characters, realistic growth, and a delightful romantic storyline. Fans of Emily Henry and Katherine Center will likely find this book to be a standout addition to their reading lists.

As they engage in summer activities, their relationship flourishes, with Ethan providing support during Ali's divorce mediation.

Ali, a loving mother coping with her own mother‚Äôs death and navigating a divorce, is a professional organizer who, despite struggling to maintain her own home, creates a magical space for her kids. Ethan, perceived as unreliable by his family, has forged a fulfilling life and brings joy to Ali‚Äôs world through his impressive actions.
This charming and humorous story makes for an ideal beach read. Though it starts off slow and somber, it quickly gains momentum, skillfully weaving together romance and touching moments.

Set in Beechwood, NY, this story beautifully weaves together elements such as rescue dogs, endearing children, skateboarding, beach outings, and a picturesque backyard with a creek. The setting creates a cozy, magical atmosphere that enhances the narrative.

The novel beautifully explores themes of grief, healing, family dynamics, and the potential for new love. It skillfully balances tender moments with humor, highlighting the significance of joy and connection.

review: This story is engaging and well-paced, captivating me to the point where I nearly finished it in one sitting, pausing only at Chapter 36. It kept me hooked from beginning to end, making me eager to return to it even during mundane tasks like cleaning the fridge. The transitions and themes of self-actualization stood out as particularly compelling.

This story features relatable and authentic characters, particularly the protagonist‚Äîa single mother and professional organizer navigating life after divorce. The exploration of family drama, pre-teen dynamics, and interactions with neighbors enriches the narrative. Additionally, the identity theme and self-improvement journey are skillfully crafted.

The author's writing is both witty and heartfelt, giving the story a delightful blend of humor and emotion. Kristen DiMercurio's narration is outstanding, vividly bringing the characters and their feelings to life. The references to classics like *The Awakening* and *Wuthering Heights* enrich the narrative with a thoughtful literary dimension.

Set in the fictional beach town of Beechwood, New York, near Connecticut and Long Island, the story boasts a charming and vivid backdrop. The blend of beach town ambiance with suburban and Manhattan elements enriches the overall atmosphere, elevating the narrative.

This story resonated with me on multiple levels, particularly regarding its themes of loss, self-care, and communication with the deceased. It masterfully balances lighthearted moments with emotional depth, resulting in a truly satisfying read.
conclusion: *Summer Romance* is a delightful and emotionally resonant novel that combines humor, heart, and self-discovery. It‚Äôs the author‚Äôs best work yet, and I‚Äôm eager to explore more of her writing. The engaging plot, relatable characters, and vivid setting make it a must-read.

The family drama, pre-teen dynamics, and interactions with neighbors added depth to the story. The identity trope and self-improvement journey were well-executed.

- **Setting and Atmosphere:**  
  The fictionalized beach town of Beechwood, New York, near Connecticut and Long Island, provided a charming and vivid backdrop. The beach town vibe, combined with the suburban and Manhattan settings, created a rich atmosphere that enhanced the story.

- **Writing Style and Narration:**  
  Annabel Monaghan's writing is witty and heartfelt, making the story both humorous and touching. Kristen DiMercurio's narration was excellent, bringing the characters and emotions to life. The inclusion of books like *The Awakening* and *Wuthering Heights* added a literary layer to the narrative.

- **Emotional Impact:**  
  The story resonated deeply with me, especially the themes of loss, self-care, and speaking with the deceased. It balanced lighthearted moments with emotional depth, making it a satisfying read.

- **Comparison to Author's Other Works:**  
  This is my third book by Annabel Monaghan, and I enjoyed it even more than *Nora*, which I gave 5 stars. It surpasses *Same Time*, which I rated 2 stars. In my opinion, this is her best book so far.

- **Recommendation:**

**Conclusion:**  
*Summer Romance* is a delightful and emotionally resonant novel that combines humor, heart, and self-discovery. It‚Äôs Annabel Monaghan‚Äôs best work yet, and I‚Äôm eager to explore more of her writing. The engaging plot, relatable characters, and vivid setting make it a must-read.

review: In her encounter with Ethan Hogan, she finds herself eager to don "hard pants" and wear lip gloss to the dog park, all in pursuit of that elusive "Champagne Summer." As their connection deepens, she discovers he's someone from her past, which sets the stage for a summer romance she knows will end when he returns to Massachusetts. This tension over whether she can protect her heart from inevitable heartbreak kept me thoroughly engaged.

In this poignant narrative, we meet Ali Morris, a single mother of three, as she faces the dual anniversaries of her mother's death and her husband's divorce request. For the first time, Ali feels truly alone and grapples with her new reality. However, as summer unfolds, she embarks on a transformative journey, gradually becoming the person she has always aspired to be.

The poignant memories and flashbacks of her mother evoke a sense of shared loss, making you feel as if you are mourning alongside Fancy. I felt a profound connection to Ali‚Äôs journey and her emotional growth throughout the narrative.

I couldn‚Äôt put this book down, yet I found myself wanting to savor every word. I absolutely LOVED it! After devouring *Nora Goes Off Script* and *Same Time Next Summer* last summer, I eagerly anticipated this release on June 4th.
I‚Äôm calling it now: this will be the must-read romance of the summer. A heartfelt thank you to Penguin Group Putnam and NetGalley for providing the ARC of this book.
conclusion: Annabel Monaghan has crafted a deeply engaging and emotionally resonant novel that balances romance, personal growth, and heartfelt nostalgia. Ali Morris‚Äôs journey is relatable and inspiring, and the chemistry between her and Ethan Hogan is both charming and bittersweet. This book is a must-read for fans of summer romances and character-driven stories.

review: Set in the quaint town of Beechwood, NY, this story unfolds a poignant love tale intertwined with a deep character study. It follows Ali, who is facing divorce and coping with her mother's recent death, and Ethan, a lawyer wrestling with his family history and personal demons. Together, Ali and Ethan form an immediate bond that catalyzes their growth, guiding them toward becoming their true selves.

Ali is a professional organizer and a mother of three, grappling with her own life even as she cherishes her work and children. Ethan is a well-developed character whose carefully constructed life is disrupted by Ali. His childhood nickname, Scooter, along with his family's view of him as unreliable, adds intriguing depth to his persona. Both protagonists are authentic and relatable, embodying strengths, flaws, and quirks. The secondary characters shine as well, from Ali's late mother, portrayed through flashbacks, to her tween daughters, her 6-year-old son, and a charming elderly neighbor. Ethan's parents, who run an inn and caf√©, bring warmth and vitality to the narrative, while Ali's soon-to-be ex-husband serves as a fittingly clueless and careless counterpart.

The author‚Äôs writing style is exquisite, especially in the dialogue, which effectively brings the characters to life. The rich details throughout the story emphasize the uniqueness of each character, making them feel genuinely real.

This book is both life-affirming and emotionally engaging, prompting deep reflection on my own experiences. The author skillfully manipulates the reader's emotions, crafting a story that resonates profoundly.
conclusion: *Summer Romance* is a beautifully written, emotionally rich novel that combines a heartfelt love story with well-developed characters and an engaging small-town setting. The protagonists, Ali and Ethan, are relatable and compelling, and the secondary characters add depth and authenticity to the narrative. The author's writing style shines, making this book a highly recommended read.

review: This story follows Ali Morris, a professional organizer facing turmoil after her mother's death and her husband's departure. Juggling her responsibilities as a mother to three children, Ali's life is chaotic. The narrative centers on her unexpected summer romance with Scooter (Ethan), her best friend's younger brother, who has returned to sell his parents' house. Their relationship develops slowly, as Ethan supports Ali during her divorce while she helps him sort through his family's belongings. Ultimately, the story is a journey of self-discovery for Ali, showcasing her growing confidence as she learns to assert herself and define her desires.

Ali Morris stands out as a relatable protagonist grappling with grief, divorce, and the challenges of single parenthood. Her compelling growth throughout the story is engaging. Ethan, affectionately known as Scooter, embodies a supportive and patient golden-retriever-type male lead who falls for Ali first, guiding her through her struggles. review: The story follows Ali, a single mother of three and a professional organizer, as she grapples with the loss of her mother and the upheaval of her recent divorce. Her chaotic life takes a turn when she encounters Ethan at the dog park, sparking a summer romance. However, the narrative extends beyond their relationship, showcasing Ali's personal growth and her quest to reclaim her independence.

**Ethan:** A well-developed character, he shines through the single perspective. His emotions and actions feel authentic, and his relationship with Ali and her children unfolds naturally, eschewing a clich√©d family dynamic. 

**Ali:** A richly drawn character, her compelling journey from a life of sweatpants to one of autonomy is inspiring. The exploration of her relationship with her mother reveals the effects of societal pressures, illuminating how even love‚Äîdespite good intentions‚Äîcan sometimes be detrimental.

The author's writing style is lauded for its depth and beauty. Their distinct voice transforms the book into a true work of literature, elevating the story and distinguishing it from other romance novels.

The story explores themes of growth and love, encompassing not just romantic connections but also familial and self-love. It examines how love can sometimes be detrimental and emphasizes the importance of cherishing our time with loved ones, even in the face of inevitable loss.
conclusion: Summer Romance by the author is a deeply moving and beautifully written novel that goes beyond a simple romance. It explores themes of personal growth, love, and autonomy, with well-developed characters and a compelling plot. The author's writing style elevates the story, making it a standout read. I highly recommend this book, praising its depth and emotional resonance.

review: This women's fiction novel, enriched with a strong romantic theme, centers on a 38-year-old woman grappling with grief, divorce, and motherhood. However, the narrative swiftly transitions to her empowering journey of self-discovery and rediscovering love. The uplifting plot inspires resilience and motivates readers to confront their own life's challenges.

The FMC is a well-developed character with a compelling growth arc, transitioning from a doormat to someone who perceives herself and her world in transformative ways. Ethan, the love interest, is perfectly portrayed‚Äîearnest, smitten, transparent, and deeply respectful, especially of her role as a single mom. Their character development and interactions feel both authentic and satisfying. The romance is rooted in respect, consideration, and attraction, emphasizing responsible adult behavior. Notably, Ethan honors the FMC's boundaries and encourages her to make choices without regrets. The story concludes with a Happy For Now (HFN) ending, which, while stable, leaves me craving more, such as an epilogue.

This story features excellent, relatable writing with a tender and heartwarming tone. The author skillfully navigates the FMC's complex emotions, striking a balance that avoids overwhelming the reader. Themes of self-care, motherhood, healing from trauma, and the importance of love and boundaries are beautifully portrayed.

**Language:** Mild language is used without any strong swearing (e.g., no f-words). **Spice:** Intimate scenes are portrayed in a PG-13 manner, featuring implied rather than explicit details. **Trigger Warnings:** Key themes include divorce and the death of a parent.
conclusion: This is a heartwarming and relatable story of healing, self-discovery, and love. The FMC‚Äôs growth, Ethan‚Äôs endearing character, and the well-balanced romance make it a compelling read. While the HFN ending left me wanting more, the overall journey was uplifting and satisfying.

review: Ali's character is profoundly moving, especially in her fierce love and dedication to her children. Her recognition of the challenges of motherhood, though difficult, is admirable and inspiring. It is empowering to witness her journey of self-advocacy after years of suppressing her own desires and needs. Ethan also stands out with his unwavering love and kindness. His endearing gesture of memorizing Ali's high school valedictorian speech adds depth to his character. His pursuit of passion against societal expectations and his role in uplifting Ali make him both relatable and lovable.

This book embodies the essence of women's fiction, a genre I particularly enjoy. Its evocative writing style fosters a deep connection to the characters and their challenges. The narrative skillfully captures the messy and frightening aspects of life while simultaneously providing a sense of hope and reassurance.

This book offers a refreshing take on the romance genre, presenting a story that is realistic, raw, and beautifully crafted. It authentically explores the complexities of grief, divorce, and the journey to rediscover happiness. Ali‚Äôs experience of navigating grief, learning to coexist with it, and ultimately finding love again resonates as a true and relatable narrative.

review: This book was full of unexpected twists, reminiscent of *Nora Goes Off Script*. The early chapters were a whirlwind, and the depth and resolution of the story ultimately earned it a 5-star rating for me.

In the author's works, women are often depicted as meek and grieving, embarking on journeys to rediscover their lost joy and strength. These characters are deeply relatable, and it was an honor to accompany them as the author revealed their world. The male main character possesses a unique ability to meet people where they are, creating a supportive space for them to become their best selves without expectations‚Äîa trait I found particularly compelling.

The phrase "It's all of it" serves as the heartbeat of these works, uniting themes of resilience, memory, and self-discovery. Her talent for creating emotionally resonant stories inspires me to revisit her earlier work, *Nora Goes Off Script*.
I read the last 90% of the book in one sitting, staying up until 3 a.m. The story was so compelling that I couldn't put it down, and I can't wait to revisit it for a re-read.

conclusion: This book was an unexpected gem, delivering emotional depth, compelling characters, and a whirlwind of a plot that kept me hooked until the early hours of the morning. The storytelling is both heartfelt and masterful, making this a standout romance that I‚Äôll definitely revisit.

review: I admired Ali's growth and her choice to prioritize her own happiness over Pete's opinions. However, I felt the story could have better highlighted Pete's suffering resulting from his selfish actions. My strong dislike for Pete stemmed from his behavior, and I wished he faced greater consequences, perhaps not finding happiness until he changed. I particularly enjoyed the dynamic between Ali and Ethan, where Ethan's kindness stood in stark contrast to Pete's toxicity.

The story poignantly explores the anguish of being ridiculed by a partner, highlighting how even children can perceive such harmful behavior. It effectively delves into themes of self-worth and the process of moving on from toxic relationships.
This novel profoundly affected me, creating a deep emotional connection through its exploration of grief, especially concerning the loss of parents and loved ones.
conclusion: This novel is a deeply emotional and thought-provoking read, exploring themes of grief, toxic relationships, and personal growth. While I appreciated Ali's journey and the introduction of Ethan as a positive influence, I wished for more focus on Pete's suffering as a form of karmic justice. Overall, it was a compelling story, but my personal desire for retribution kept it from being a perfect read.

review: I‚Äôve discovered a new favorite rom-com author! I absolutely loved this book. The author skillfully weaves together themes of motherhood, grief, and love, all while creating relatable and kind characters. I truly didn't want it to end. Thank you for crafting such a warm and enjoyable story!

The line ‚ÄúAnd then she died‚Äù echoes my own experience, as I began my first journal entry after my dad's passing (with the pronouns changed, of course). This sentiment, though simple, marks a definitive turning point‚Äîlife was one way until her death, and then everything changed. I had to navigate my new reality alone. I was one person, and then she died, transforming me into someone else entirely. If you're part of the ‚Äúdead parent club,‚Äù this will resonate with you. This book beautifully captures Ali's journey of self-discovery after losing her mom, offering comfort and connection.
I highly encourage you to pick it up when it's released‚ÄîI plan to buy a few copies myself! A big thank you to NetGalley and Penguin Group Putnam for the opportunity to read an early version.
This rom-com goes above and beyond typical tropes and predictable storylines, offering a refreshing take on the genre.
conclusion: This heartfelt and skillfully written rom-com transcends typical genre tropes, offering a deeply emotional and relatable story about motherhood, grief, and love. The author‚Äôs ability to craft believable characters and intertwine complex themes makes this book a standout. It‚Äôs a must-read for anyone who enjoys stories with emotional depth and authenticity.

**Aspects:**  
- **Author's Writing Style and Skill:**  
   - "I have a new favorite rom-com writer. Wow, I loved this."  
   - "The way Annabel intertwines motherhood, grief, and love, while keeping her characters kind and believable‚Ä¶ I didn‚Äôt want this one to end."  
   - "Thank you to Annabel Monaghan for writing such a fun, heartfelt book."  

- **Emotional Depth and Relatability:**  
   - "The line 'And then she died.' is exactly how I started my first journal entry after my dad died (with the pronouns swapped of course)."  
   - "That sentiment may seem simple, but it‚Äôs a clear line in the sand. It‚Äôs the ultimate transition point. Things were this way, and then she died‚Ä¶ So I had to figure things out on my own. I was this person, and then she died. And now I am a different person."  
   - "I‚Äôm babbling, but I assume it makes sense if you‚Äôre in the dead parent club. And this book will fill your cup as you read about Ali‚Äôs journey to becoming a new person after losing her mom."  

- **Genre and Storyline:**

*Summer Romance* is the ideal summer read, and I highly recommend picking up a copy next week! It's perfect for fans of small-town settings, single-parent narratives, closed-door romance, self-discovery, best friend's brother tropes, and themes of family and found family.

The well-integrated presence of Ali‚Äôs children heightens the emotional stakes and strengthens Ethan's connection to the family.
The writing is both engaging and humorous, especially in the delightful "meet cute" at the dog park. The tone effectively balances emotional depth with lighthearted moments.

The book elicits a wide spectrum of emotions, from tears to laughter, resulting in a profoundly moving and enjoyable experience. Ali's journey of self-discovery through her relationship with Ethan is both heartwarming and inspiring.
conclusion: This novel is a heartfelt and engaging story of love, loss, and self-discovery. review: Ali's journey is remarkable as she evolves from a discontented housewife to a woman who embraces her strength, confidence, and passions. Ethan, her love interest, shines as a supportive and devoted partner, making him an exceptional book boyfriend. Additionally, Ali's reflections on her past‚Äîparticularly her marriage and relationship with her mother‚Äîadd significant depth to her character.

This book is both engaging and easy to read, seamlessly blending light-hearted romance with serious themes. The author skillfully balances humor and charm with emotional depth, crafting a story that truly resonates with readers. The audiobook and paperback formats enhance the experience, keeping me captivated from start to finish.

This book transcends the typical summer romance by exploring profound themes such as risk-taking, love, grief, and self-discovery. The protagonist, Ali, grapples with life after her mother's passing, a divorce, and the challenges of raising three children, adding depth to the narrative. It highlights the significance of boundaries, accountability, and authenticity in one's life.

This book resonated deeply with me, especially through Ali's journey of grief, self-reflection, and empowerment. The quotes in the review beautifully capture the emotional depth of the story. I found the portrayal of motherhood and the intensity of a mother's love particularly moving. Ali‚Äôs home organization hobby and passion for accounting add a delightful quirkiness to her character. I relate to her struggle to balance societal expectations with her own desires, making her journey feel all the more personal.

The romance between Ali and Ethan is thoughtfully developed and seamlessly integrated into the main plot. Their relationship is both fulfilling and supportive, emphasizing the significance of genuine partnership. The story features appealing tropes, such as best friend's brother, childhood acquaintances turned lovers, and closed-door romance.
conclusion: This summer romance novel exceeded expectations by blending light-hearted romance with profound themes of grief, self-discovery, and empowerment. The character development, particularly Ali's growth, is unmatched, and the romantic elements are both heartwarming and deeply satisfying. review: The ending was beautifully executed, with the house, charm, fence, and Thanksgiving dinner coming together perfectly. The emotional payoff made the heartbreak throughout the story worthwhile, leaving me feeling fulfilled and satisfied.

The FMC is a professional organizer whose chaotic personal life makes her relatable and endearing. Her journey toward regaining confidence and independence is inspiring. Additionally, the portrayal of her struggles as a single mother and her daughter's challenges in sixth grade adds depth to her character.

The notion of a "champagne summer," which celebrates living life to the fullest, is both uplifting and inspiring. The poignant juxtaposition of joy and loss, particularly symbolized by the arrival of a dog, captures the bittersweet essence of life. The theme of taking charge of one‚Äôs own experiences resonates throughout the narrative, weaving seamlessly from the protagonist‚Äôs high school speech to Ethan‚Äôs present-day affirmation.

This book offers a heartwarming romance intertwined with deeper themes of grief, confidence, independence, and empowerment. The emotional journey of the female main character resonated with me, leaving my heart full.

The humor, from the hard pants debate to the FMC's disdain for dog parks, was both hilarious and relatable. I found her habit of wearing a blazer at home to tackle tasks particularly validating, as it mirrored my own quirks.
conclusion: This novel is a heartfelt, humorous, and deeply relatable story that balances romance with themes of grief, empowerment, and life‚Äôs bittersweet nature. The FMC‚Äôs journey, the witty humor, and the perfect ending left me feeling emotionally fulfilled. The author has crafted a story that resonates on multiple levels, making it a truly memorable read.

review: The story centers on Ali, a professional organizer grappling with the aftermath of her mother's death and her separation from her husband. It's a straightforward yet engaging setup: Ali meets Ethan at a dog park, and the two dive into a summer romance as he helps tidy up his parents' house.

In *Nora Goes Off Script*, Ali, a relatable single mom raising three children, shares a compelling journey with Ethan. The story emphasizes their emotional connection and chemistry, prioritizing their relationship over hurried physical intimacy. It thoughtfully explores their struggles to navigate their circumstances while celebrating the joy they discover in each other's company.

This story offers a refreshing take on romance after divorce, capturing the complexities of love intertwined with parenting and daily life. It skillfully depicts the adventures of juggling soccer practices, co-parenting schedules, and summertime activities with children. This grounded realism makes the narrative relatable and engaging, even in the absence of the glitz and glamour associated with younger, unmarried characters.

The writing flows seamlessly, beautifully illustrating how love can unexpectedly enter our lives, particularly for a single mom. The book delves deeply into the characters and their emotional ties, evoking a strong sense of yearning. I found myself with a lump in my throat while reading, a clear sign of a five-star romance.
conclusion: The author's *Summer Romance* is a beautifully written, emotionally resonant story that stands out for its focus on character development, realistic portrayal of post-divorce romance, and the power of yearning. It‚Äôs a five-star read that lingers in your heart long after you finish it.

review: In this heartfelt story, Alice, a thirty-something mother, navigates the challenges of divorce while grieving her mother's loss and embarking on a journey of self-discovery. Enter Ethan, her best friend‚Äôs younger brother‚Äîa recently single lawyer who has secretly harbored feelings for Alice since high school. Their serendipitous encounter at a dog park sparks a charming and engaging romance that captivates readers.

Alice's journey of self-discovery, her newfound strength against her ex-husband, and her reconnection with family are vividly portrayed. Ethan's long-standing feelings for Alice add depth to his character, though I found it slightly challenging to envision them as a couple, as Alice felt much older than him in my mind. Their relationship develops organically, and I appreciated that Alice continues to spend time with Ethan even after recognizing his true identity. However, the age difference and Ethan's persistent longing occasionally make their dynamic seem uneven.

The story is charming and heartwarming, striking a delightful balance between romance and personal growth. Instead of leaning heavily on romantic elements, it emphasizes Alice's journey of self-discovery. The light tone makes it an ideal summer read.
conclusion: This novel is a delightful summer read with a charming romance and a strong focus on self-discovery. While I had some reservations about the age dynamic between Alice and Ethan, the story‚Äôs heartwarming tone and relatable characters make it an enjoyable experience.

review: This contemporary adult romance follows Ali, a thirty-something mother of three, as she embarks on a journey of rediscovering love after facing the losses of her mother and her marriage. A year after her husband leaves, Ali is struggling to hold her life together when a chance encounter at the dog park presents an enticing possibility for romance. The story delves into themes of love, loss, and the value of living in the present. It powerfully conveys that one should never regret loving someone, even with the awareness of potential loss. This poignant lesson is artfully woven into the narrative, creating a heartfelt and uplifting experience.
conclusion: *Summer Romance* is a heartfelt and well-written novel that beautifully captures the complexities of love, loss, and self-discovery. The characters are relatable, the chemistry is electric, and the themes are both touching and thought-provoking. I highly recommend it!

review: *Summer Romance* is the perfect novel to welcome the season. Feeling lost, she asks her mother for a sign, which arrives unexpectedly when her dog, Ferris, urinates on the most handsome man at the dog park. The man, Ethan, takes it in stride, amused and intrigued by Ali, encouraging her to reengage with her life.

In her exploration of a ‚Äúweary housewife‚Äù navigating the complexities of divorce, Ali‚Äôs journey resonated deeply with me. Many mothers will undoubtedly see reflections of themselves in her struggles. The witty banter and heartfelt moments between Ali and Ethan brought genuine smiles and laughter, making the story both humorous and emotionally rich. Overall, it‚Äôs an incredibly engaging read.
This author has become an automatic choice for me. Their ability to create vivid, relatable characters is so impressive that I often find myself believing they could be real people.
If you enjoy closed-door romance stories, this one is definitely for you!

review: Ali's character arc was beautifully rendered, capturing her struggle with self-worth and the tendency to prioritize others over herself in a painfully relatable way. Subtle details, such as her adding cinnamon to her coffee for her husband's sake despite not enjoying it herself, poignantly illustrated her sacrifices and the imbalance in their relationship. This book compellingly portrays the dangers of neglecting one‚Äôs own happiness in favor of others. It highlights the significance of mutual love and care in relationships, particularly through Ali‚Äôs journey to discover someone who genuinely values her.

This book had a profound emotional impact on me, especially as someone who endured their parents' divorce at a young age. Ali's perspective resonated deeply; her longing for her husband's love, juxtaposed with his obsession with cycling, was both heartbreaking and soul-crushing. Phyllis's passing was incredibly moving as well. In her final days, enjoying eggs and vanilla pudding while witnessing Ali find genuine love, I felt my heart swell. It was as if Phyllis could leave this world in peace, knowing Ali was finally cared for.
conclusion: This was a sweet and emotionally impactful book that touched on themes of love, sacrifice, and self-worth. The characters felt real and relatable, and the story left a lasting impression. I absolutely loved it and couldn‚Äôt put it down.

review: In *Summer Romance*, the author tells the story of Ali, a single parent grappling with the complexities of divorce, grief, and raising three children. review: The novel centers on Ali Morris, who is grappling with a divorce, the passing of her mother, and a personal slump. As she navigates these challenges, Ali finds solace in a summer romance with Ethan, a skateboarder-turned-lawyer and her best friend's younger brother. While the romance is significant, the heart of the story lies in Ali's journey of self-discovery and her quest to reclaim control of her life.

Ali's journey is both authentic and relatable, thanks to her flawed nature. The characters are refreshingly realistic, embodying the imperfections of everyday life‚Äîlike Ali shaving her legs while wearing reading glasses and hoarding unwanted granola bars. A central theme of the story is Ali's growth over the summer as she rediscovers her identity after losing herself in the roles of wife, mother, and caretaker of grief.

The author's writing is lauded for its relatability and humor. By crafting genuine, human characters, the story fosters a strong connection with readers. A notable strength is the author's ability to balance emotional depth with lighthearted moments.

I found Ali to be highly relatable and saw myself in her character in many ways. This novel has established the author as a must-buy for me. Meeting her during the book tour in Charleston, SC, was a delightful experience that deepened my appreciation for both the book and the author.
conclusion: *Summer Romance* is a heartfelt and relatable novel that combines a charming summer romance with a deeper exploration of self-discovery and personal growth. The author's writing style and ability to create relatable characters have made her a favorite author for this reader.

review: I loved both main characters for their authenticity, and their ages (38 and 36) provided a refreshing contrast to the typical 20-something protagonists. Ali's feelings of being past her prime and her mixed emotions about the future resonated deeply with me.

This book strikes a perfect balance, being both sweet and subtly sexy in a PG-13 way, which I genuinely appreciated. It's a relatable, romantic, and humorous read, making it well-rounded and enjoyable. Having loved the author's debut adult novel, *Nora Goes Off Script*, this latest work has cemented their spot in my top three favorite romance writers. Their books consistently delve deeper than their covers and titles imply, and I‚Äôm eager to explore more of their writing in the future.

The author adeptly captures Ali's grief following the loss of a parent and the dissolution of a loveless marriage. Ali's thoughts and reactions resonated deeply with me, providing a sense of understanding and connection that made me feel less alone.

I found myself laughing at the clever details, such as the contrast between hard and soft pants, Ali's Costco underwear, and the imposing woman in a belt at the dog park. The book's relatability even motivated me to give my kitchen a thorough cleaning.

The title initially misled me, but the book proved to be wise, insightful, and profound. While I expected a well-written and swoon-worthy romance, it ultimately delivered much more than a typical love story.
conclusion: This book exceeded my expectations, blending humor, romance, and emotional depth in a way that felt both entertaining and profoundly relatable. The author's ability to capture the nuances of grief, love, and self-discovery has made her one of my favorite authors. I highly recommend this novel to anyone looking for a story that is as wise as it is heartwarming.

Her journey of self-reflection‚Äîrecognizing the choices she made for others instead of herself‚Äîis explored thoughtfully and respectfully, making her happiness even more rewarding to champion.
*Summer Romance* is the quintessential summer read‚Äîemotional, humorous, and filled with hope. It left me with the satisfying sensation of a cathartic cry followed by a comforting embrace.

This book is a swoon-worthy romance that focuses on Ali‚Äôs journey to rediscover and fall in love with herself, rather than just pursuing a relationship with a man. It also explores themes of grief and the complex emotions tied to losing a loved one. These poignant moments were especially impactful, leaving me teary-eyed by the end.
conclusion: Overall, *Summer Romance* is a beautifully crafted novel that combines a swoon-worthy romance with profound emotional depth. Ali‚Äôs journey of self-discovery, coupled with the exploration of grief and love, makes this a standout read. It‚Äôs emotional, funny, and hopeful‚Äîa perfect summer romance that leaves you feeling uplifted.

review: The book defied my expectations and turned out to be a delightful surprise!

You formed a friendship with an eighty-six-year-old woman‚Äîmy age when we first met. While I could have opted for hired help over the years, I chose to share a life enriched by our flowers and our cherished moments together.
The love story is enjoyable, but the exploration of grief, loss, and death truly stands out, often becoming the highlight of my day.

I cried three times while reading. The overarching themes of grief, loss, and mortality were the most impactful elements. They explore life's fragility‚Äîsymbolized by eggs and flowers‚Äîand the beauty of loving despite inevitable endings. Truly exquisite.
conclusion: The novel delivered a deeply emotional experience, with its exploration of grief, loss, and love leaving a lasting impression. The unexpected depth of the side plots and the poignant portrayal of relationships made it a truly exquisite read, far surpassing initial expectations.

review: Despite its serious themes of divorce and parenting, the book remains enjoyable and entertaining. Its well-balanced pacing keeps the reader engaged from start to finish.

Ali is a vividly crafted character who embodies authenticity and depth. As she navigates a divorce, manages her household, works, and parents, she searches for joy and fulfillment. The arrival of Ethan enriches her journey, and their summer romance blossoms with genuine warmth. The relationships throughout the book are masterfully written, featuring nuanced and believable interactions that enhance the overall enjoyment of the story.

What I love about this author's work is its relatability and focus on real-life situations, setting it apart from typical romances. Many romance novels feature characters who lack the complexities of everyday life‚Äîoften childless, unmarried, and carefree. In *Summer Romance*, however, the main character, Ali, is a 38-year-old professional organizer and mother of three. While she assists others in organizing their lives, her own is a delightful mess, making her both authentic and relatable.
conclusion: I thoroughly enjoyed *Summer Romance* by the author. The relatable characters, real-life situations, and well-crafted relationships made it a standout read for me. It‚Äôs a fun and entertaining story that also delves into deeper themes, making it both heartfelt and enjoyable.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Relatability and Real-Life Situations:**  
  What I love about Annabel Monaghan's books is that they are more relatable and feature more real-life situations than most romances. In many romances I read, the characters often lack the complexities of real life‚Äîthey‚Äôve never been married, have no kids, no mortgages, etc. In *Summer Romance*, the main character, Ali, is a 38-year-old professional organizer with three kids. She helps others with their organizational needs, but her own life is quite messy, which makes her feel authentic and relatable.  

- **Character Development:**  
  Ali is a well-developed character who feels real and multi-dimensional. She‚Äôs navigating a divorce, running her household, working, and parenting, all while trying to find joy and happiness again. Ethan, who enters her life, adds another layer to her journey, and their summer romance feels genuine and heartfelt.  

- **Plot and Pacing:**  
  Despite the heavy themes of divorce and parenting, the book manages to be fun and entertaining. The pacing is well-balanced, and the story keeps you engaged throughout.  

- **Writing Style and Relationships:**  
  The relationships in the book are very well-written and feel authentic. The interactions between characters are nuanced and believable, making the story even more enjoyable.  

**Conclusion:**  
I thoroughly enjoyed *Summer Romance* by Annabel Monaghan. The relatable characters, real-life situations, and well-crafted relationships made it a standout read for me. It‚Äôs a fun and entertaining story that also delves into deeper themes, making it both heartfelt and enjoyable.

Throughout the narrative, Ali faces a range of challenges, including interruptions from her children, pets, neighbors, friends, exes, and professional commitments, adding depth and complexity to her journey.

Ali emerges as a relatable protagonist navigating grief and the journey of rebuilding her life. Ethan‚Äôs sincere interest in her adds depth to their relationship, while the presence of her toxic ex, Pete, underscores the theme of how Ali deserves to be treated and loved. This exploration heightens the emotional stakes of the story.

Set in a quaint New York town, complete with a beach, a family-owned inn, and a diner, this story beautifully captures the charm of a close-knit community. The lively interplay of neighbors who are always in each other's business enhances the warmth and humor throughout.

review: I was surprised by the portrayal of the female main character, Ali. She comes across as a pushover, often failing to stand up for herself or her children against her ex-husband, Pete. From the beginning, it's evident that Ali is emotionally disengaged from her children and neglects her own well-being, frequently wearing dirty clothes without concern. It‚Äôs clear she could benefit from therapy to address her feelings and regain a sense of self.
I enjoyed the summer vibes and the writing style, which has inspired me to explore more works by this author.
I didn't dislike it, but I know it won't leave a lasting impression. Although it was a short book, it somehow felt drawn out.
conclusion: While the book had some enjoyable elements, such as the summer vibes and writing style, it fell short in terms of memorability and character development. Ali‚Äôs lack of agency and poor parenting choices were frustrating, and the romantic relationship with Ethan felt awkward at times. The supernatural element of her dead mother talking to her didn‚Äôt resonate well, and the story overall felt longer than it needed to be. Despite these issues, the author‚Äôs writing has potential, and I‚Äôd be open to trying more of their work.

review: The first two-thirds of the book were engaging, but the third act felt rushed and less assured. The narrative relied more on telling than showing, which diminished the overall storytelling. An unusual structural choice‚Äîswitching to a new chapter and day whenever a meal was served‚Äîwas disruptive and interrupted the flow. The ending felt abrupt, leaving some loose threads unresolved, which was unsatisfying. I was taken aback to find the Author‚Äôs Note instead of a more polished conclusion. This lack of resolution affected my overall enjoyment of the book.

The romance started as a delightful slow burn, immersing me like diving into a plush, luxurious bed. Ethan, the charming and devoted male lead, evoked a clear image of Ryan Reynolds in my mind. Unfortunately, around the 66% mark, the romance lost its magic. The initial excitement faded, and the emotional connection felt disappointingly flat.

While I had some concerns with this book, I admired the author's skill in creating a slow-burn romance with genuine emotional depth. After enjoying *Nora Goes Off Script*, I'm open to giving the author another chance in the future.

This story explores grief, loss, and the challenge of moving forward. While the blurb hinted at these themes, the emotional depth surpassed my expectations. The narrative shifts toward women‚Äôs fiction in the latter half, introducing more somber and introspective moments that overshadow the earlier charm.
conclusion: While the book started strong with a compelling slow-burn romance and emotional depth, it faltered in the third act with rushed pacing, an abrupt ending, and unresolved threads. The author‚Äôs stylistic choices, such as abrupt chapter transitions, also disrupted the flow. Despite these flaws, the initial charm and my appreciation for the author‚Äôs previous work leave me open to trying another of her novels.

review: The plot was overly predictable. While romance novels typically adhere to a familiar structure, this one was especially easy to predict within the first twenty pages. Although there's a certain comfort in knowing the story will end happily, the absence of surprises left it feeling less engaging for me.

Ali, the protagonist and a single mother navigating divorce, grief, and the challenges of raising three spirited children, embarks on a relatable journey of self-discovery. However, I found her growth somewhat reliant on Ethan's influence rather than her own resilience. Ethan‚Äôs character often came across as performative; his charity work felt more like a device to showcase his kindness than a true reflection of his personality, leaving me less captivated by him than I'd hoped. In contrast, Phyllis, Ali‚Äôs elderly and bookish neighbor, truly shone as a standout character. I adored her and would gladly help her organize her overflowing bookshelves if she ever needed it!

This book resonates strongly, especially for those facing similar life challenges. Although I didn‚Äôt enjoy it as much as others may have, I appreciate its appeal and believe it‚Äôs worth a read if the premise intrigues you.
This book aligns more with literary fiction than traditional romance, so it's important to manage expectations if you're seeking a typical romance narrative.
conclusion: Overall, *Summer Romance* by the author is a relatable story with a predictable plot and a focus on self-discovery. While I didn‚Äôt connect deeply with the romance or Ethan‚Äôs character, Ali‚Äôs journey and the delightful presence of Phyllis made it a worthwhile read. I‚Äôd recommend it to those who enjoy literary fiction with a touch of romance, though it may not satisfy readers looking for a more traditional love story.

- **Genre Expectations:**
   - The book leaned more toward literary fiction than romance. This might be something to keep in mind if you‚Äôre expecting a traditional romance novel.

- **Character Development:**
   - Ali, the protagonist, is a single mum dealing with divorce, grief, and raising three lively kids. Her journey of rediscovering her identity was relatable, though I felt her growth was overshadowed by Ethan‚Äôs influence rather than her own strength.
   - Ethan‚Äôs character felt somewhat performative, especially his charity work, which seemed like a tool to highlight his niceness rather than a genuine part of his personality. I didn‚Äôt warm up to him as much as I‚Äôd hoped.

- **Side Characters:**
   - Phyllis, Ali‚Äôs elderly, bookish neighbor, was a standout. She was the best side character, and I absolutely adored her. If she ever needs help organizing her overflowing bookshelves, I‚Äôd gladly volunteer!

- **Relatability:**

**Conclusion:**
Overall, *Summer Romance* by Annabel Monaghan is a relatable story with a predictable plot and a focus on self-discovery. review: As an action-oriented reader, I typically prefer stories that focus on the present rather than delving deep into a character's thoughts or memories. I found Ali, the protagonist, to be a compelling character. review: The introduction of the love interest marked a pivotal moment for Ali, providing her with much-needed stability. I ended up skipping through many of the romantic passages due to their blandness. Ali's choice to break up over logistical concerns, such as the reluctance to relocate or enter a long-distance relationship, was frustrating‚Äîhe seemed like a great fit for her and her kids. I appreciated the scenes in which Ali stood up to her husband during the divorce arbitration, particularly with Ethan's support; it effectively revealed her husband's true, unpleasant nature. The resolution, where Ali confronted her own faults in the marriage and acknowledged her mother‚Äôs imperfections, was particularly strong.

From the outset, I struggled to connect with Ali, the protagonist. Her inability to move on from her mother‚Äôs death, even after two years, took a toll on both her life and her children‚Äôs well-being. I found her emotional stagnation frustrating, especially as it contributed to her husband leaving her. While I respected her grief, I did not enjoy navigating her prolonged despair. Additionally, her idealized memories of her mother felt disingenuous, further diminishing my appreciation for her character.
The book is well-written and features compelling moments that kept me engaged, despite my issues with the characters and romance.
conclusion: While the book had its strengths, particularly in its writing and some plot resolutions, I struggled to connect with the protagonist, Ali, and found the romantic subplot lackluster. Her prolonged grief and questionable decisions made it hard for me to fully enjoy the story, though there were moments of growth and insight that I appreciated.

I would read anything by this author. The title *Summer Romance* instantly captured my attention, delivering exactly what I sought.
conclusion: *Summer Romance* by Monaghan is a delightful blend of humor, heart, and romance. It balances emotional depth with lighthearted moments, making it a perfect summer read. Fans of Abby Jimenez and similar authors will especially enjoy this charming story.
